dt: {bc}to court favor by a cringing or flattering manner

dt.t: The dog was {wi}fawning{/wi} on its master.

pt: {sc}fawn{/sc} {sc}toady{/sc} {sc}truckle{/sc} {sc}cringe{/sc} {sc}cower{/sc} mean to behave abjectly before a superior. {sc}fawn{/sc} implies seeking favor by servile flattery or exaggerated attention.
{sc}toady{/sc} suggests the attempt to ingratiate oneself by an abjectly menial or subservient attitude.
{sc}truckle{/sc} implies the subordination of oneself and one's desires or judgment to those of a superior.
{sc}cringe{/sc} suggests a bowing or shrinking in fear or servility.
{sc}cower{/sc} suggests a display of abject fear in the company of threatening or domineering people.

et: Middle English {it}faunen{/it}, from Old English {it}fagnian{/it} to rejoice, from {it}fægen, fagan{/it} glad {ma}{mat|fain:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to court favor by a cringing or flattering manner
to show affection —used especially of a dog

dt: {bc}one still unweaned or retaining a distinctive baby coat

et: Middle English {it}foun{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}feun, foon{/it} young of an animal, from Vulgar Latin {it}*feton-, feto{/it}, from Latin {it}fetus{/it} offspring {ma}{mat|fetus|}{/ma}
shortdef: a young deer; especially : one still unweaned or retaining a distinctive baby coat
